title: How to see the possible | via modal continuity
description:
To go deeper:

"Continuity as a Guide to Possibility," Australasian Journal of Philsoophy, https://www.researchgate.net/publication/264244809_Continuity_as_a_Guide_to_Possibility

"Extending Modal Knowledge," in Modal Epistemology after Rationalism, edited by Bob Fischer & Felipe Leon, https://www.researchgate.net/publication/317542501_Modal_Epistemology_After_Rationalism (coming to my website soon).

An argument for supreme power:

1. If the foundation’s power were arbitrarily limited, it could have more power. (by the nearby principle)
2. The foundation cannot have more power. 
(Because: it automatically has whatever powers it could have.) 
3. Therefore, the foundation’s power is not arbitrarily limited.

The version in my term paper was a little different. I develop that version in “Why is There Anything?” (with Weaver) here: https://www.academia.edu/20392976/Why_is_There_Anything
 
Toy around with it. Find new paths. 

For more resources on worldview development, see joshualrasmussen.com

title: Does life only get harder? How your worldview can bring hope.
description:
Positive psychology gives you tools to help you cope with life's dark tunnels. But positive psychology can only go as far as your worldview will allow it. How positive can you be if you know your life is headed toward a dark or meaningless end? This video highlights the significance of the big and little stories of your life, and how they impact your experience of everything.

To learn more about building your worldview, visit Prof. Rasmussen's website at https://joshualrasmussen.com.


Video info:

Figure source: The Happiness Curve: Why Life Gets Better After 50 by Jonathan Rauch

All video clips and images used by permission.  Thank you to Pixabay, Pexels, and Videvo for offering a great library of royalty-free pictures and videos.

title: From an infinite regress to a necessary foundation
description:
I uncover an idea that has been hidden in the battle of ideas. It took me a long time to see this clearly myself. While I have understood for a long time that the existence of a *necessary foundation* of the world is consistent with an *infinite regress* of causes, I didn't see so clearly how an infinite chain of causes actually makes the existence of a necessary foundation all the more pressing. 

QUESTIONS:

If you have questions about why I propose that the probability of continued existence diminishes without a necessary foundation, you might find this link helpful: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_GyNcuI4p6c

ADVANCED:

You might recognize Aquinas' distinction between two types of regresses: (i) an *accidentally ordered* (horizontal) regress across time, vs. (ii) an *essentially ordered* (vertical) regress at any given time. Some philosophers have argued that even if the regress of accidentally ordered causes is infinite, still, there must be a first cause in the chain of essentially ordered causes. In this way, one could are that a necessary foundation is compatible with an infinite horizontal regress.

However, I wish to say something further. In fact, Aquinas' distinction is irrelevant to my proposal. For even if both types of regresses (horizontal and vertical) are infinite, that does nothing to remove the possibility of, or need for, an ultimate explanation of existence. After all, a universe that is infinite along *any* line of dependence is still a universe, and no universe is explained solely by its causal lengths. By contrast, a necessary foundation (whether itself infinite or not) can provide the ultimate explanation of all contingent causal lines, whether those lines are essentially ordered, accidentally ordered, or ordered in some other way.

ARGUMENTS FOR A NECESSARY BEING:

See http://joshualrasmussen.com/

title: Problem of Evil: Moral Argument (4 of 4)
description:
Here is a more technical unpacking of the argument, followed by responses to some objections:

M = "there is a moral standard" 
G = "there is a perfectly good foundation"

1. There is evil.
2. If there is evil, then there is a moral standard (moral truths) that distinguish between good and evil.
3. Therefore, M
4. Probability of M on G = 1.
5. Probability of M on ~G is less than 1.
6. ∴ M supports G.

The probability is epistemic, understood as rational degree of expectation.

Objections:

Q1. If the foundation were evil, that would equally entail M. 

Reply. That's consistent with the conclusion.  Consider that *every* data is entailed by infinitely many hypotheses, yet we obviously don't infer that no data supports *any* hypotheses. For example, genetic similarities support biological evolution, yet this same data is also entailed by the hypothesis that a supernatural demon created all species with their genetic similarities.

Moreover, there are asymmetries between good and evil:
1. A standard that distinguishes between good and evil is itself good, not evil.
2. Evil always depends on something good. For example, evil actions require some knowledge, but knowledge is an intrinsic good. Evil actions involve exchanging a greater good (like a relationship) for a lesser good (like temporary pleasure), which implies that there is already good.

In short, you can't have evil without something good (such as a moral standard), but you can have good prior to all evil.

O2. M is already maximally likely with or without G.

Reply. We need to distinguish prior from posterior probability. M's posterior probability may be maximal on your moral experiences, but *prior to* all moral facts, its probability is far from maximal. Compare: the fact that 2 + 2 = 4 may be certain to you, but it is not thereby certain that 2 + 2 would equal 4 were there no mathematical truths. 

Note that *a priori* probability -- a probability you can sense a priori -- is not the same as *prior* probability.

Taking a step back, the hypothesis that there is a perfect being is relatively simple and has high predictive power. It predicts, among other things, that there are both necessary rules of proper reasoning -- logic -- and necessary moral laws. It is interesting that reality should "happen" to have necessary truths, including truths about how persons should behave. While these necessary truths may trivially have an objective, non-epistemic probability of 1, it is far from trivial that there are necessary truths at all. Reality just happens to include necessary truths that are expected to exist if there is a perfect being. This is strange and striking. It gets even more striking when we consider that reality just happens to include the right parameters required for the existence of *moral communities* who can apprehend moral laws. 

The argument is reinforced by a certain Russellian paradox of propositions expressed in plural quantification. The paradox arises from the premise that purely Platonic propositions would automatically exist for any xs. But that’s impossible, for there can’t be a proposition about all and only the propositions that aren’t about themselves, since such a proposition is about itself if and only if it is not -- a contradiction. The best solution to this puzzle of which I am aware is that propositions exist explanatorily posterior to mental activity. This result makes the existence of necessary moral propositions all the stranger, absent a perfect mind.

This argument is a seed. In your hands, you can develop this seed in a variety of ways.

title: Problem of Evil: Theodicy (3 of 4)

title: Problem of Evil: Assessing Probability (2 of 4)

title: Problem of Evil: Logical Analysis (1 of 4)
description: I consider whether a perfect Being could create a world that contains imperfections. This video begins a series on the problem of evil.

title: Is truth in the eye of the beholder?
description:
I display a distinction between beliefs that match your perspective vs. beliefs that match things beyond your perspective. 

I unpack these ideas much further in Defending the Correspondence Theory of Truth, Cambridge University Press (https://www.amazon.com/Defending-Correspondence-Theory-Joshua-Rasmussen/dp/1107057744).

title: "Test all things..."
description:
I aim to remove two barriers to the commitment to follow reason and evidence *wherever* they lead you.

I also aim to highlight a virtue I see in many of my non-theist friends: the courage to face reality. 

This video is part of a larger vision I have where theists and non-theists see, understand, and appreciate each other.

title: How to solve political polarization
description:
As a philosopher, I like to understand the ROOT of things. As I observe our political conversations and fights, I think I see a root of the problem: we have felt *devalued* in these debates. Respect has been broken. 

It is time to transform our conversations by building a foundation of respect. Truth matters, but truth flow is interrupted by broken respect. We have the power to break these barriers and *reverse* political polarization. It starts with a decision: make the people who disagree with us feel valued. Then we build the foundation for positive cultural transformation.

....As an addendum, I'd like to share a place where I personally struggle with the implementation of my proposal. It occurs when I witness someone devalue someone else for their political or philosophical ideas. I feel a strong desire to protect the person who is devalued. My temptation, then, is to protect and defend someone in a way that actually devalues the attacker. For example, I might point out the simple-mindedness of the attacker who arrogantly shames people naively. Now there is a place to expose vice. The problem, however, is that in many contexts of communication exposing vice makes things worse by fueling the problem of polarization. Also, I am being hypocritical if I devalue someone for devaluing someone. How do I get out of that problem? As a first step in answering that question, I find it is helpful for me to redirect my aim by asking myself how I can serve people with insights that matter to *them*. Sometimes when I want to expose someone's bad thinking (on any subject), it is more about my need to feel known and appreciated than about service. Once I recognize this, I can shift into service mode and free myself from wasting time living below the line: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fLqzYDZAqCI.

title: How to ruin your worldview
description: I give you 3 tips to help you increase your stock of false beliefs.

title: How to lead in the world of ideas
description: I share 4 traits of highly effective leaders in the arena of ideas.

title: How many senses do you have?
description:
I offer reasons to think you have at least 9 basic senses, if not 10.

For more research on 10, see Plantinga's God and Other Minds.

title: How to see objective value (17 of 20)
description:
I give an argument for the existence of some *value* outside of you, and then I assess three of the biggest objections.

Sources for further study:
1. A scientific case for the objectivity of beauty (a form of value) in flowers: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gT7DFCF1Fn8ith
2. On the objectivity of moral value: https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-realism
3. A commonsense defense of objective moral value: http://www.shenvi.org/Essays/ObjectiveMoralValues.htm
4. A professional philosophical defense by Mike Huemer: http://joshualrasmussen.com/ethical.html
5. How to classify the options: https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-anti-realism
6. Tedx talk on functional value of beauty: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wRdq-CU3xu8

I'd like to add here a couple disclaimers about the part of the video where I compare reason vs. trust. First, I do not mean to imply that there are not very reasonable people who offer tough-minded and important objections to value-realism. There are! I also don't mean to imply that trust is not itself a valuable means toward truth. It surely is! These are not easy subjects, and I have high respect for those who arrive at a different viewpoint. My goal in this video is to stimulate further thinking, especially for those who may have taken for granted the "value = opinion" view and are stuck on some of the objections I discuss.

Also, if you happen to be a grade school teacher who has taught the "value = opinion" view, I'd like to thank you, first, for your valuable serve, and thank you also for considering the critique I offer in this video. I wish you the best, especially since I think you are adding objective value to others in many ways.  :)

title: How core values influence your worldview
What does supreme greatness imply? (16 of 20)
description: I show how to unpack the concept of a supremely great foundation

title: How supreme greatness solves the puzzle of dependence (14 of 20)
description:
I point out some advantages of the Supreme Greatness theory of an ultimate explanation. Enjoy! 

If you have questions or feedback, comment below or feel free to contact me at jrasmus1@gmail.com!

title: Interview with Robin Collins about minds, materialism, and scientific progress
description:
I open the interview by distinguishing three main views about human minds: (i) reductive (else: eliminative) materialism (all is material), (ii) idealism (all is mental), and (iii) dualism (mind ≠ material). Then Collins and I have an impromptu conversation about some (but not all) common motivations for strict materialism, such as:

1. Simpler ontology.
2. The causal problem.
3. Mental-physical correlations.
4. The argument from brain death.

Collins also sows seeds of reasons he doubts materialism. Let me say here that I recognize that each of the considerations we discuss invites further inquiry, and so I offer this exchange not as a way to trump materialists, but as an invitation for further inquiry and consideration.

This conversation introduces you to some of the concepts in the philosophy of mind. For further reading if you want to master many of the basic concepts, theories, and arguments, I recommend Searle's book, Mind: a Brief Introduction (https://www.amazon.com/Mind-Brief-Introduction-Fundamentals-Philosophy/dp/0195157346).

title: 8 best objections to the "contingency" argument (episode 10 of 20)
description:
The contingency argument seeks to show that there is a necessary (self-existent) foundation of contingent things.  I assess the following objections: 

Objection 1: There is no totality ("universe"). 
Objection 2: Fallacy of composition. 
Objection 3: Infinite regress 
Objection 4: Quantum Mechanics 
Objection 5: The first event is special 
Objection 6: Bootstrapping 
Objection 7: The universe is necessary 
Objection 8: The argument is too lofty                  

For more on why infinity doesn't remove the need for an explanation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0Z1fZAvm9UU&t=14s  

For more on why infinity doesn't constitute an explanation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tHsmnxK1fsw

title: The unifying value of truth-seeking
description: I share how *belief-based* unity can hinder the development of your understanding of the world, while *value-based* unity can help you go far in understanding more and more.

title: How disdain leads to mistakes
description: I consider a common source of error, and then propose a practical way to avoid that source of error by shifting your mindset toward *serving* people with ideas.

title: How to argue for your immateriality
description: Sequel: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SfB3NlNVpw8&, where I address your valuable questions and objections in the comments on this video. Thank you to everyone for your valuable feedback!

title: How to use arguments as tools rather than weapons
description: I share 3 strategies I use to get arguments to serve me in developing my understand of the world.

title: How to escape the land of imagination (explaining existence: 11 of 20)
description: The argument in this video is loosely based upon my article, "A new argument for a necessary being," Australasian Journal of Philosophy.

title: 4 "worldview" tips for developing your theory of reality
description: I share some commonsense, but often neglected strategies I use to make progress in my understanding of the big questions of life.

title: 5-year-old ANSWERS the trolley problem
description: Unscripted.

title: 5-year-old thinks her thoughts have no shape
description: Philosophy professor grills his daughter about the nature of her thoughts. Unscripted.

title: A "contingency" argument for a self-existent foundation (episode 9 of 20)
description:
I give a classic argument from contingency for necessary existence. For the technically savvy, here is the symbolic formulation:

P1. (∃x) x=x
P2. (∀xx) (∃y)(¬(y ≺ xx) ∧ D(xx,y)) v ¬(∃y)(¬(y ≺ xx) ∧ D(xx,y))
P3. (∀xx) (¬(∃y)(y ≺ xx ∧ ☐ (∃z) z=y)) → (∃w)(¬(w ≺ xx) & D(xx,w)) 
C. (∃x) ☐ (∃y) y=x

‘∀xx’ is a plural quantifier, and ‘≺’ expresses “is among”.

Note that my argument from irrelevant differences seems unaffected by whether the “contingent reality” in question is a thing or things (infinite or finite, causally connected or not).

If you have objections, see if I address it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=asCqyTCaoNM

title: The Power of Reason
description: I show how you can use reason to develop your understanding of the world.

title: A closer look at why things continue to exist (episode 8 of 20)
description: I give a probability-based argument against the theory that the universe continues to exist without any explanation. This video is part of a larger project of developing a sound worldview using the light of reason.

title: How atheists and theists talk past each other on "who made God?"
description: I consider some ways I see atheists and theists sometimes misunderstanding each other when talking about where God came from. I suggest how atheists and theists might instead work together using reason to help each other develop an understanding of the foundation of existence.

title: Introducing the puzzle of persistence (episode 7 of 20)
description: Why do things continue to exist? This question poses a unique challenge to the theory that the universe has always existed without any explanation at all. I unpack this challenge for your consideration.

title: How your insights can change the world -- Rasmussen at Azusa Pacific University
description: Rasmussen's book -- the one he mentions in this talk -- is now available for pre-order, How Reason can Lead to God: https://www.ivpress.com/how-reason-can-lead-to-god

title: Why a circular chain fails to explain existence (episode 5 of 20)
description: I suggest that even if something can explain itself in SOME sense, there is still a deeper question as to why there is that very circle of explanation. If we say the circle explains itself in some (strange) sense, still, there remains a clear sense in which the question of why it actually exists, rather than not, has not thereby been adequately answered.

title: Why an infinite regress fails to explain existence (episode 3 of 20)
description: Rather than argue against the possibility of an infinite regress, I consider whether an infinite regress could, by itself, provide an adequate explanation of our universe. I also respond to a classic objection from David Hume.

title: A closer look at why an infinite regress doesn't explain existence (episode 4 of 20)
description: I give a more advanced analysis of the infinite regress.  This video is for anyone who wants to get to the "bottom" of this subject.

title: Robin Collins on fine-tuning, origin of reason, and God
description: Robin Collins is the world's leading expert on the fine-tuning of our universe. In this interview, Collins shares his latest discoveries on the fine-tuning for science and discoverability. He later gives an interesting argument against following reason to a conclusion that undermines reason itself. He then argues that a mind at the foundation of all things can best explain the origin and value of reason itself. At the end, he offers tips for how to develop one's theory of the world.

title: Advanced objections to a self-existent foundation (episode 12 of 20)
description: Reason cuts through three of the most advanced objections to a self-existent Foundation. You may encounter these objections in academic halls or sophisticated corners of the Internet. See if you recognize all three.

title: 4-year-old OWNS philosophy professor in debate over God
description: Philosopher challenges his daughter's belief in God. Unscripted.

title: Why existence probably didn't come from nothing? (episode 6 of 20)
description:
See how a reality from nothing creates the Problem of Chaos.

If you are tempted to reply that we've never observed absolutely nothing, then I must clarify something: when I say "x comes from nothing," I don't mean that there is nothing at all when x comes to be. Rather, I mean that there is no thing that produces x. That is, x appears without any cause (whether deterministic or indeterministic) or any relevant condition. My argument, then, is that if anything can come to be without a cause, then, by the principle of irrelevant differences, we have a problem of chaos. 

If you have other responses or ideas, feel free to post them below! Your ideas are valuable to me.

title: What is the nature of a "self-existent" foundation? (episode 13 of 20)
description: What does the light of reason reveal about the self-existent foundation of all dependent things?

title: Why does anything exist? (episode 1 of 20 on Explaining Existence)
description:
It is puzzling how there could be *something* rather than simply nothing (ever). Discover how "self-existence" can solve this puzzle.

This video is part of Worldview Design with Professor Rasmussen.
